noun.description: A set of moral principles, especially ones relating to or affirming a specified group, field, or form of conduct.
examples: the puritan ethic was being replaced by the hedonist ethic

adjective.description: Relating to moral principles or the branch of knowledge dealing with these.

origin: Late Middle English (denoting ethics or moral philosophy; also used attributively): from Old French éthique, from Latin ethice, from Greek (hē) ēthikē (tekhnē) (the science of) morals, based on ēthos (see ethos).
